Coauthor

I am a coauthor on a paper studying the impact of artificial intelligence on US hiring from 2010 onwards. We use establishment level data on vacancies with detailed occupational information comprising the near-universe of online vacancies in the US. We classify establishments as AI exposed, that is, likely to replace workers with AI based on their detailed skill mix garnered from their job postings in 2010. We then study how AI exposure affects overall hiring and hiring composition.
Masters Candidate
Sep 2018 - Sep 2020 · 2 yrs 1 mo
My master's thesis is augmenting the 1940 US census with more detailed information about the work done by each person in the labor force. The purpose of this project is to study the nature of new work in 1940. I use a BERT model to predict each person's job complexity based on the job's textual description in the 1939 Dictionary of Occupational Titles. The trained model achieves an accuracy of 80% in the classification task and is able to predict job complexity for earlier and later years.

Building 46, Goosens Lab
We are studying fear extinction by exploring the formation of new
memories on every level of neuroscience; from genes to neurons to behavior. We hope to find a correlation between the formation and extinction of fear memories and the neuronal circuitry associated with these memories. For example, introducing a conditioned stimulus without the associated unconditioned stimulus will create new memories and new neuronal circuits will be recruited that will contradict the previous, fearful memories. By doing so, we hope to contribute to the discovery of new therapies for anxiety-type disorders and other psychiatric diseases.

6.004 Lab Assistant
Sep 2015 - May 2017 · 1 yr 9 mos
In this course, I guided and taught students to write code and design circuits for digital systems. The majority of the coursework comes from labs, which I was responsible for helping students debug and receive credit for. The labs begin with MOS transistors and logic gates and progresses through increasingly complicated digital systems, the highlight of which is the fully operational gate-level design of an RISC processor (a.k.a. "The Beta"). Other lab assignments include a Tiny OS, an ALU, a Turing machine algorithm for checking if a string of parentheses is balanced, and Quicksort written in a low-level language specifically for the course adapted from x86 Assembly.

For more information on course content: http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-004-computation-structures-spring-2009/index.htm
6.149 Lab Assistant
Jan 2016 · 1 mo
I guide and teach students with little to no programming experience in writing, testing, and debugging Python software. Students start with types and simple arithmetic and progress through programming concepts in Python during the course, culminating in basic object-oriented programming and inheritance. Some of the programs built include a game of Hangman (including an ASCII stick figure), a game of Battleship using Python's graphics library, and a game of Scrabble.
In addition, this position required me to proofread problem sets, labs, and exams before they are assigned to the students. I also had to grade exams given to the students.
6.117 Lab Assistant
I guide and teach students with little to no experience with electrical engineering and circuits to read schematics, use lab equipment, and build circuits from scratch. The students learn how to use oscilloscopes, logic analyzers, multimeters, function generators, soldering kits, and other tools. Some of the circuits built include an ECG amplifier and a USB powered audio amplifier.
Course description: http://web.mit.edu/6.117/www/index.html

Sep 2015 - Dec 2015 · 4 mos
I guided students through the software and design labs throughout the course. The software labs consisted of writing Python software that either extends the last homework assignment or will be used later on in the design lab that week. The design labs forced the students to use the concepts learned that week in the context of robotics, e.g. getting a robot to follow a light using an analog circuit, getting a robot to make it from one point in a maze to another using basic search algorithms, designing an optimal impulse response for the robot's change in speed and direction, etc. My job specifically was to give checkoffs, hold office hours, and help students debug their work.

For more information on course content: http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-01sc-introduction-to-electrical-engineering-and-computer-science-i-spring-2011/index.htm

Yoqneam, Israel
One of Mellanox's major products is switch boards for communication between supercomputers. High speed communication links/cables are used to connect the ports on the switches so that packets of data can be sent back and forth between the switches. Of course, because these links are imperfect copper cables, the information packets get corrupted as they travels through the link. My job as an intern on this team was to fix this problem so that the information would be as correct and uncorrupted as possible.
I first had to design error correction and cancellation filters for the high speed links. This involved researching different types of filters for error correction, figuring out how to model the impulse response of the links (i.e. mathematically represent the corruption), and choosing the best filter coefficients according to my model. I used Matlab to confirm my ideal filters and to select these coefficients by writing search algorithms that optimized the coefficient values according to data that had been sampled from the links. Finally, I tested and revised my designs using the firmware API belonging to a testing switchboard.
Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)
1 yr 1 mo
Academic Teaching Initiative (ATI) SAT Prep Math and Writing Tutor
Oct 2013 - Oct 2014 · 1 yr 1 mo
High school students who are looking to improve their scores on the SAT and SAT Subject Tests signed up for this program during the fall and spring semesters. I lectured weekly on the Math section, the Writing section, and test-taking in general.
For the Math section, I focused on teaching the students how to problem solve, since they had already learned enough math to complete the exam. For the Writing section, I focused on teaching the students how to hear when grammar in a sentence sounds wrong (multiple choice section) and how to write a concise, smart essay in under 30 minutes (essay section). In both classes, I also spent time teaching the students how to improve their ability to find the right answer in the event that they're dumbfounded by showing them patterns in how the test-makers write the exams.
Undergraduate Student Researcher (UROP)
May 2014 - Aug 2014 · 4 mos
MIT Nuclear Reactor Laboratory
My supervisor at the lab was developing the shape and configuration of a neutron detector that, when neutrons were shot at it, produced an image indicating where the neutrons landed. My job was to figure out the optimal geometry and positioning of the detector for the project.

The simulation of shooting neutrons had already been written by someone else using C/C++. I had to sift through the code, figure out how it worked, and use this simulation to mathematically model where the neutrons were landing, how the positioning of the detector affected the neutrons' landing positions, and what the detector's 3D shape should be (ultimately a combination of 3D conic sections). I used Python to write simulations to optimize all of this.

experience:
Assistant Professor
Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Jul 2018 - Present · 3 yrs 11 mos
Cambridge, MA
The Bryson Lab at MIT is interested in developing a new framework for dissecting host-pathogen interactions in Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. Nearly 1/3 of the global population is infected with Mtb; however, there is no protective vaccine that is approved to work in human populations. Our lab is focused on understanding how macrophages and Mtb interact and how their interactions result in productive control and death of the bacterium. We are developing new biological tools, computational, and experimental models to understand the determinants of control of Mtb survival.

Certified Adversarial Robustness for Deep Reinforcement Learning
Deep Neural networks, used in commercially available driver assistance systems, can fail on hardly detectable adversaries, for example, white stickers on the road. This work has invented an add-on, real-time defense algorithm to certify the robustness of Deep Reinforcement Learning algorithms to such adversaries. Patent pending.
Safe Reinforcement Learning with Model Uncertainty Estimates
Deep neural networks can fail overconfidently on novel observations, for example, an uncollaborative pedestrian on a personal vehicle. This work pioneers a reinforcement learning framework that detects novel observations and cautiously avoids them by reasoning about the neural network's predictive confidence.

TrueBranch: Metric Learning-based Verification of Forest Conservation Projects
International stakeholders increasingly invest in offsetting carbon emissions, for example, via issuing Payments for Ecosystem Services (PES) to forest conservation projects. Issuing trusted payments requires a transparent monitoring, reporting, and...
Machine Learning-based Estimation of Forest Carbon Stocks to increase Transparency of Forest Preservation Efforts
Efforts to maintain and restore rainforest, one of the cheapest carbon sinks, are limited by the amount of funding. This work creates deep-learning-based forest inventories from drone imagery, collected by locals, to cheaply and accurately estimate the amount of tree-sequestered carbon. The transparent estimation of carbon attracts funding from companies, aiming for carbon neutrality, and allows locals to generate a livelihood from maintaining and rebuilding rainforest.

name: Fadok Richard
about: As a cultural anthropologist, I study how contemporary architects and industrial designers in the United States are rethinking their most fundamental assumptions about the nature of design in the midst of the ongoing environmental crises of the Anthropocene. My interdisciplinary scholarship spans across the anthropology of science and technology (or STS), design studies, and the environmental humanities. My dissertation uses historical and ethnographic methods to inspect a multi-disciplinary design practice known as biomimicry. My forthcoming project will ask how architects think about and design for animals. I am currently a PhD candidate in the History, Anthropology, and Science, Technology, and Society Program at MIT. I have my M.Sc. in Biomedicine, Bioscience, and Society from the London School of Economics and an Sc.B. with honors in Neuroscience and Science and Society from Brown University.My previous research projects have explored the life sciences, including microbiology and neuroscience. In a past life, I was a neuroscience researcher. You can find some of my scientific publications here.

name: Jacob (Jake) Lueders, PE
about: I am an Engineer Officer in the United States Army and driven by my philosophy of Faith, Family, Fitness, and Fun. I am currently a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, studying in the System Design and Management Program. I previously Commanded Bravo Company, 249th Engineer Battalion (Prime Power), and was tasked with providing temporary, emergency, and contingency utility-grade power for both disaster response and military operation. I was responsible for the training, performance, safety, health, morale, and welfare of 84 assigned Soldiers to Bravo Company, managed a budget in excess of $600,000, and maintained over $19 million in equipment. Throughout my career in the Army, I led Soldiers through complex training and engineer missions, liaised with senior leaders in both the government and civilian sector, deployed to Afghanistan, and served in a technical role with the US Army Corps of Engineers. I am a proponent of lifelong learning, ensuring that I both seek out opportunities and provide opportunities to my subordinates to constantly improve both personally and professionally, and aim to be value-added to every team I join.

name: Ian Bouche
about: Hi! I'm Ian, and I'm thrilled to enter the professional sphere at a time when so much technology seems at the cusp of profound revolution. I insist on using my skillset to change big things about the world. I have a passion for figuring out how things work. That's why I'm seeking to understand a new 'big' system, and be put into a position where I can tackle multidimensional problems pertaining to it. Be it a budget, a microchip, a city or a rocket, if its deep and complicated, I'm interested.I have significant experience with electronics which I've been able to apply both as a hobbyist and as a researcher. Working with Prof. Wolfgang Ketterle at his lab in MIT, I built electronic frameworks to optimize the extremely precise optical systems required to create Bose-Einstein condensates, even reverse-engineering the communication protocols that certain lab equipment used to send custom RS-232 commands without the expensive conversion tool.Currently I am a part of Prof. Kerstin Perez research group at MIT, in which I have had a broad host of experiences. For one, I worked on the silicon-lithium (Si(Li)) semiconductor detector array inside the General AntiParticle Spectrometer (GAPS). GAPS is a balloon-borne experiment designed to test dark matter models by measuring cosmic antideuteron flux at low energies. Partaking in this hunt for antiparticles has taught me innumerable skills, among them experimental design, electrical engineering, particle physics theory, data analysis through ROOT (C++) and python, semiconductor theory and fabrication, and effective communication and teamwork with peers in the lab and the international GAPS team. My work with GAPS began when I was an undergraduate, first focusing on programming Monte Carlo simulations of GAPS using the GEANT4 simulation framework, built on CERN’s ROOT data analysis software for C++. Since September 2021, employed as a full-time researcher at the Perez lab, I have been working more directly with the Si(Li) detectors, testing their performance and troubleshooting the delicate electronics. Most recently, I’ve been involved in fabricating additional Si(Li) semiconductor detectors for GAPS in the MIT Nano facility by etching, cutting, and evaporating lithium onto the p-type silicon material at high temperatures.I'm looking to the future with my varied past in mind, and open to a wide range of opportunities. If you're interested in my profile for whatever reason, send me a message!

Automated EMG feature extraction for machine learning of hand postures based on muscle activity. Implemented machine learning algorithms for offline classification of several types of grasps. Sensorimotor Control Laboratory
Our lab studies Brain-Machine Interfaces (BMIs) that control upper-limb prostheses. In particular, we are interested in how the brain controls complex hand movements. The human hand has about 30 dimensions in contrast to a human arm with only 7 dimensions. BMIs that control human arms have already been demonstrated with decent accuracies. What type of interface is needed to extend the control from 7 to 37 dimensions forms the central topic of research of the lab.

name: Louis DeRidder
about: Louis DeRidder is a Ph.D. student in the collaborative Harvard-MIT HST MEMP program, where he will take classes at the Harvard Medical School, MIT Engineering School, and Sloan School of Management. For his thesis, working with Profs. Robert Langer and Giovanni Traverso, he will develop a medical device for superior drug delivery of chemotherapeutics. Additionally, he will investigate the gut-brain-immune axis, in search of a novel mechanism to intervene to treat neurological diseases. If successful, he plans to launch a biotechnology company from this work to bring these technologies to market, and thus improve the lives of people suffering from cancer and neurological diseases.

As a student, the focus of my work is to move towards a more sustainable future and a more resilient today though the development of methods to improve thermal comfort while decreasing energy use. Selected highlights of my work has has involved:
-predicting bio-aerosol (COVID) movement, 
-programming and troubleshooting building management systems (BMS),

Energy Efficiency Engineer (Analyst)
Sep 2014 - Apr 2016 · 1 yr 8 mos
As an analyst-level Energy Efficiency Engineer within Cadmus, I worked on a variety of projects within the Engineering Services Division.

-I was a crucial team member in a program evaluation of Ductless Mini-Split Heat Pumps across Massacusetts and Rhode Island. As a principal member of the team, I was involved in the process from deployment to collection to reporting. The resulting report is groundbreaking in that it established performance models in a variety of conditions and across 250 different heat pumps.

-During the winter of 2014-2015, I designed and performed a technical demonstration of Heat Pump Clothes Dryers for a Massachusetts client. The demonstration isolated the impact on energy use, drying duration, and overall performance based on modifications to individual set points of the unit. The final report which I authored conveyed the implications of behavior in the expected energy savings of the units, as well as outlined conditions under which energy savings were negated. Several non-energy benefits were also reviewed during the scope of the study and quantified to illustrate the implications of different drying technologies.

-As part of the Evaluation, Measurement, and Verification team, I performed dozens of project reviews across several states and a variety of building purposes. I focused mainly in the HVAC components; notably boilers, roof top units, steam traps, variable air volume systems, digital direct control (DDC) systems, building shell improvements, and lighting.
Research Assistant
Jun 2014 - Aug 2014 · 3 mos
After my Bachelor's, I continued working in the Building Technology lab isolating differences in energy utilization between the most energy intensive and least energy intensive laboratories on MIT's campus. Specifically, the focus of the study was on biomedical and chemical laboratories, and trying to tackle their reputation as the most energy-intensive labs while working around the unique constraints that each laboratory space required. The culmination of the project led to a set of low-capital changes to the buildings and building operations that would result in significant energy savings.

name: Syed Shayan Zahid
about: My mission in life is to empower people to be who they are, and remove their barriers to enable them to pursue their dreams. I value interpersonal connections, and trust in using our voices and commonalities to elevate one another.My belief is that everything is interconnected. I pursue my interests in the the fields of sustainability, social impact, languages, and the performing arts. My professional passion lies at the intersection of engineering and sustainability in the aviation industry. It all started from a collaboration with the Boeing Company to come up with a mechanism to recycle carbon fiber waste in their manufacturing facilities. I realized the true impact of anthropogenic waste and emissions, and joined the MIT Laboratory for Aviation and the Environment (LAE) to further my goals. I currently work on reducing anthropogenic high-altitude emissions to mitigate climate change impacts caused by commercial flights. If you find your interests resonating with mine, please reach out to me and let's collaborate to make this world a better place!
experience:
Research Assistant - Lab for Aviation & the Environment (LAE)
Massachusetts Institute of Technology · Part-time
Aug 2020 - Present · 1 yr 10 mos
Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States
I collaborate with the FAA to investigate and develop cutting-edge emission reduction technologies for gas turbine engines. Our goal is to develop solutions that would mitigate the environmental impacts of aviation without compromising engine performance. 

I worked in a 7-member team to evaluate the effectiveness of using novel water injection technology in different parts of an aircraft engine. I analyzed the gas turbine engine cycle and optimized the trade-off between engine performance and emissions using this approach. Our research showed that this method yields up to an 80% reduction in nitrous oxide emissions.

Additionally, I designed and sized a fuel tank to store cryogenic liquid hydrogen inside an aircraft’s fuselage. This involved working in a 12-member team. I conducted stress, material, and pressure vessel analysis to come up with a design that is the most weight-efficient for the aircraft. Our efforts furthered research in this new area and we determined that this method can help bring the aviation industry close to the goal of zero emissions.
Product Validation Intern
Cummins Inc. · Internship
Mar 2020 - Aug 2020 · 6 mos
New York, United States
I led 4 different projects during my tenure.

COMPONENT FAILURE INVESTIGATION: 
- Led investigation into identifying the cause of debris-related lube system failure in engines.
- Introduced and implemented novel testing strategy to speed up the identification of engine failures; now incorporated into a technical standard for midrange engine testing. 
- Championed a proactive approach towards identifying and resolving design and manufacturing failures. 

SETTING ROBUST SYSTEM SPECIFICATIONS: 
- Revised inadequate technical specifications and guidelines for cooling systems cleanliness of next-gen engines.
- Developed a quantified framework for cooling system engineers; eliminated dependence on visual inspections. 
- Prioritized holistic testing of most failure-prone components within the engine.
- Collaborated with SMEs to collect data and define maximum allowed debris limits in engine cooling system; used CAD (Creo) to model coolant cores.
- Created technical documentation to facilitate lube and cooling system engineers for product development.

PROCESS STANDARDIZATION:
- Reduced rework by creating a centralized document containing oil rifle pressure limits in the lube system of midrange engines. 
- Collaborated with global stakeholders; educated manufacturing teams on the new requirements. 

ENGINEERING DOCUMENTATION: 
- Facilitated future training efforts by documenting the complex process of extracting coolant cores from next-gen engines.
May 2019 - Aug 2019 · 4 mos
Columbus, IN
For my excellent performance during this co-op, I was awarded the ExxonMobil Co-op Scholarship.

COMPONENT TESTING:
- Determined the temperature after which oil degradation accelerated in an under-development midrange engine; owned testing efforts.
- Defined a new technical testing method that became the standard for 8.9L midrange engines. 
- Used DOE approach to identify failure causes as part of a 10-member team; analyzed field data.
- Conducted a trade-off analysis with the combustion and performance teams to determine optimal oil change interval time.
- Pioneered a new engine test for analyzing oxidation in the engine breather condensate.

PRODUCT LIFECYCLE ANALYSIS TOOL:
I helped develop an algorithm to process engine field data and look at oxidation trends with time. This tool aided in future product development and made the lube system development process more efficient.

ENGINE DUTY CYCLE ANALYSIS:
Based on engine field data, I constructed theoretical duty cycles to be tested for a fuel-in-oil dilution model. 

MENTORSHIP: 
Selected as an Intern Mentor to educate new interns on company processes and procedures.

I also standardized a cooling system cleanliness test that is projected to save $2M annually in the best case, and $10M annually in the worst case.
Product Improvement Intern
Jun 2018 - Dec 2018 · 7 mos
I led/worked on 4 different failure investigations during this tenure. From these projects, two significant projects are shared below: 

1. SYSTEM INTEGRATION
- Led a 10-member team through an investigation into exhaust component failure in an existing engine.  
- Collaborated with the drafting, validation, and design teams and component SMEs to identify the cause and cost of this failure.
- Halved project timeline to 3 months by recommending and implementing the fitting of an existing exhaust pipe with bellows onto the engine model experiencing failures.
- Proposed a solution that lowered warranty costs by $2M in 1 year. 

2. COMPONENT FAILURE INVESTIGATION AND RESOLUTION
- Initiated a project to investigate why a turboactuator component in a midrange engine was yielding warranty failures. 
- Ensured seamless handover to a project manager as the scope grew. 
- Sped up the identification of failure causes by introducing the use of the Design of Experiments (DOE) methodology. 
- Gave one of two recommendations that the company implemented; the company saved $5.6M. 

KEY SKILLS: Prototyping | CFD Analysis | Material Testing | Simulation Testing and Analysis | Testing Framework Improvement | Reporting | Data Analysis | Process Improvement | Testbed Creation | Supplier Management | Test Plan Creation | Component Validation | New Product Development | Efficiency Improvement | Mentorship | Solution Development | Design Improvement | CAD | Cross-Functional Collaboration | Project Ownership
Mechanical Engineering Intern
KSB Pumps Company Limited - Pakistan · Internship
May 2017 - Aug 2017 · 4 mos
Hasan Abdal, Pakistan
I rotated between the Sales, Manufacturing, and Design departments. I oversaw manufacturing operations of centrifugal pumps and worked in a 5-member team to improve pump efficiency and product designs. 

My team was tasked with improving pump efficiency by 2%. After studying the product design and conducting testing, we recommended that the company change the impeller blade curvature. Furthermore, to streamline this change process, we advised that the company use the mold of a previous model’s impeller blade. 

As a result, a +3% improvement was seen in pump efficiency and the project timeline was halved to 3 months.

experience:
PhD Candidate
Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Aug 2015 - Present · 6 yrs 10 mos
I am currently conducting my PhD research in characterizing the structure and function of AAA+ proteases in the Sauer Lab. 

I have taught courses 7.02 Introduction to Experimental Biology and Communication and 7.05 General Biochemistry as a teaching assistant. 

In 7.02, I worked with a small group of students to cover the topics of genetic screens, yeast display, molecular biology, recombinant expression and protein purification in a teaching lab. In two 4-hour sessions each week, I led small-group discussions in-lab regarding the experimental techniques and supervised lab procedures. I also graded and provided feedback on weekly pre and post lab reports, exams and a paper on the genetic screen conducted in the teaching lab. 

In 7.05, I designed problem sets and conducted weekly recitation sessions. After attending three weekly lectures with the students, I summarized the weekly material in a comprehensive 1-hour recitation.
Brandeis University
4 yrs 1 mo
Research Student
May 2011 - May 2015 · 4 yrs 1 mo
I completed the 4-year combined BS/MS program in biochemistry by completing the undergraduate and graduate level course requirement as well as a M.S. thesis. Through research conducted during the summer as well as the academic year in the Goldstein Lab, I completed a M.S. research thesis investigating the effect of a cardiac arrhythmia-associated mutation on the structure and function of voltage-gated potassium channels (IKs). With the combination of phage display to design specific ligands and characterization of change in function and structure of the cardiac ion channel complexes in live cells by electrophysiology and TIRF microscopy, I characterized the effect of the disease-associated mutation on IKs channels as well as potential therapeutics. 

I received the Brandeis Division of Science Fellowship in the summer of 2014, where I conducted research, attended weekly seminars with other fellows and presented my work at the Division of Science symposium.

name: Rachel Bellisle
about: As a doctoral student in the Harvard-MIT Health Sciences and Technology Program and a Draper Fellow, Rachel studies Medical Engineering and Medical Physics. She previously received a Bachelor of Science in Biomedical Engineering from the University of Rhode Island in Kingston, RI in 2018. Through the Bioastronautics Training Program, her current research with the MIT Human Systems Lab focuses on wearable technology for space and Earth applications, providing solutions for physiological adaptations in the extreme space environment and developing terrestrial rehabilitation technologies. Rachel is passionate about allowing humans to live and work safely in space, and finding ways to translate space research to terrestrial applications. Beyond her research interests, Rachel is involved in K-12 STEM (or STEAMD) outreach.

name: Stephen O'Sullivan
about: Understanding the properties and behavior of black holes in an astrophysical environment is of utmost importance to improving their detection and observability. During my PhD work, motivated by this premise, I concentrated on examining the response of a black hole due to the gravitational influence of an orbiting body. This process combined tools from differential geometry, calculus and numerical computing to produce animations of black hole event horizons using the Mayavi data visualization package. The result illustrates the fluid dynamics behavior of the horizon albeit with a negative viscosity. I was also involved in a collaboration which focussed on modeling the complexities of a black hole binary inspiral. We did so by analyzing the signals from a time-domain numerical simulation and mapping them to an analytical formalism.As a physicist in training, I enjoy problem-solving, numerical analysis and large-scale cloud computing. In my spare time, I like to hone my maths and programming skills by solving Euler problems and participating in TopCoder marathons. I am also excited by real-world problems involving geometry and graph analysis.

This project involved a parametrically controlled model of a generic building geometry which was optimized (using the NSGA-II algorithm) with regards to structural, operational energy, and daylight autonomy performance. The findings of the project reveal that conceptual design and building performance can be used simultaneously to produce high performing, aesthetically interesting designs that are highly climate specific.
Undergraduate Capstone Project
Jan 2015 - May 2015 · 5 mos
Analysis of Masonry Structures: Dome at Soltaniyeh
- As part of my undergraduate curriculum, this intensive individual research project focused on the analysis of a 14th century masonry mausoleum complex in Soltaniyeh, Iran. I developed a parametric program for thrust analysis in the dome, using Grasshopper for Rhino, to explore the role of the dome geometry and structure. In addition, I prepared a scaled 3D printed model of the dome for seismic analysis using tilt table testing. This research, which will shortly be published, is one of the first comprehensive structural analyses of this dome ever undertaken.

Massachusetts Institute of Technology · Full-time
Sep 2015 - Present · 6 yrs 9 mos
I am a PhD student in the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science department here at MIT. Under my advisor, Prof. Saman Amarasinghe, I do research in the area of compilers and high performance computing. 

In this area, I am generally interested in developing domain specific languages (DSLs) that allow non-expert programmers to write code that achieves runtime performance rivaling expertly hand-tuned code. 

More specifically, my PhD topic is on creating a DSL for implementing data compression algorithms. Data compression theory and algorithm development have been widely researched topics for several decades, but little attention has been given to the actual implementation. Current data compression implementations involve large amounts of code, most of which is un-optimized, as optimizing that amount of code is an extremely difficult task. As big data continues to take over, more and more data must be compressed, and with un-optimized code, it is (and will continue to be) prohibitively expensive to compress the necessary data, particularly while maintaining high fidelity. These issues are classic problems that high performance DSLs can be used to solve, hence the motivation behind my research topic.

Prior to starting the data compression work, I also completed my Master’s degree at MIT under Prof. Amarasinghe. My Master’s research was focused on developing a scheduling language for generating distributed and parallelized code that ran simultaneously on heterogeneous processors.

I am a second-year PhD student at MIT. I am enrolled in both the Social & Engineering Systems Program, and the Interdisciplinary Doctoral Program in Statistics. They focus on the applications of mathematics, statistics, and other computational methods to the study of socially significant questions.

• Research
My main research is on causal inference methods for drug repurposing for Alzheimer's Disease, using observational data from Electronic Health Records in the US and UK. I am currently working with Professor Roy Welsch, from the Operations Research Center and Sloan School of Management.

I am also collaborating with Dr. Leo Celi from the Institute for Medical Engineering and Science on data science questions in critical care medicine, with a focus on time series models for the prediction of adverse events.

More generally, I am interested in leveraging non-traditional data for public health. An ongoing project is on the use of news media data to model disease outbreaks, and assess the differences in health-related language between US states.

• Activities & Societies
I am contributing to the organization of MIT Policy Hackathon, leading our communications and external relations efforts.

May 2015 - Aug 2015 · 4 mos
Bremen Area, Germany
Many people begin mathematics by studying numbers. As they advance through the curriculum, they discover many different types of objects: sets, functions, groups etc. Each object has its own set of rules and relationships to other concepts. Though diverse, all of these rules and objects share a reliance on an underlying logic to make decisions about what is true and false. Similarly, as you study the logic that underlies these objects, you also find that there is also large number of logics, each sharing the same basic “logical framework”.  This is also true for logical frameworks, which all share a “Module”.  At each layer of abstraction, we get closer to a truly general representation of all of mathematics, computer science, and ideas in a general sense.

For my Bachelor’s thesis, I used these principles of abstraction to develop a language-independent automated theorem prover for the Module System for Mathematical Theories (MMT) in Scala using an agent-oriented design. This involved developing an agent-based architecture, creating proof and knowledge representation data-structures, and creating valid proof tactics for any formal type theory. This prover is general enough to prove theorems in any language of mathematics including set theory, category theory, homotopy type theory, first order logic, propositional logic, economic theories, legal theories, and many more.
Yale University Active Galactic Nuclei Research Group
Jun 2014 - Jun 2015 · 1 yr 1 mo
New Haven CT
Recently, Astronomers discovered that a black hole lies at the center of almost every galaxy in the universe. Some of these black holes are actively devouring their host galaxies, and are called Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN). It was my task to determine the distance to an AGN using only a small amount of noisy data. 

I developed an automated system to mine data on AGN and use it to predict their distances from Earth. I used Bash and SQL to query several online databases and join the relevant data together. I then processed the data using python, and fed it into a parametric model called lePHARE to estimate the distance to the galaxy. I then updated this pipeline to use my model selection tool META, which improved my results considerably.
mhamilton723/META
META - A model selection toolkit written in python. Requires sklearn and pybrain
Vector-Like Quark Research Group at ATLAS
Jun 2013 - Sep 2013 · 4 mos
Geneva Area, Switzerland
I worked with Kenan Jia under the supervision of Professor Tobias Golling and Mark Cooke from LBNL to creating a cut-based analysis to search for a theoretical particle called the “Vector-like quark (VLQ)” in the data generated from the ATLAS detector at CERN. This particle is necessary in most extensions of the standard model of particle physics without supersymmetry. This project involved studying simulated particle collisions to identify where the Vector-Like quark was likely to arise. Using this monte-carlo data and C++, we investigated a large number of analyses to find one that maximized the power of our statistical tests. This project involved large datasets, distributed computing systems, and data visualization. This was internally published in an ATLAS note (ATL-COM-PHYS-2014-474).

Disappearing Tracks Search at CMS
Apr 2020 - Present · 2 yrs 2 mos
Developed a method to identify isolated leptons that were missed by the CMS reconstruction algorithm, which were part of the background of a search for long-lived particles. This method uses a deepSets architecture which takes as input the rec. hits in the detector; shown to increase signal acceptance by 5% and reduce the lepton backgrounds of the search by 40-50% across signal regions; method has applicability to other analyses for its accuracy at identifying leptons. Working on devising another technique to suppress the other components of the background of this search.

name: Annaliese Meyer
about: (she/her) I am a PhD student in the MIT-WHOI Joint Program, focused on trace metal oceanography and proteomics, with an emphasis on applications to space exploration. Over the past several years, my research has involved taking samples from 7000 m below the sea surface to launching sounding rockets to 9000 m above ground level. I believe that being comfortable hopping between wildly different fields and environments is essential for a successful career in an inherently interdisciplinary field like astrobiology. Beyond research, I am passionate about space policy, particularly in the realm of planetary protection and responsible international cooperation in space. “Space is big. You just won't believe how vastly, hugely, mind-bogglingly big it is. I mean, you may think it's a long way down the road to the chemist's, but that's just peanuts to space.” ― Douglas Adams, The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy

Researched and designed scientific payloads to be launched to 30 000 ft. in a student-built sounding rocket. Handled live specimens and analyzed samples in the field post-launch using light microscopy, dissection and direct observation, on-site microbiological culture growth, and performed extensive reviews of the relevant current literature. Directed a specialized team of approximately 10 undergraduate students, worked with a larger team of approximately 50 students from various faculties and liaised with school and governmental agencies. Became proficient at quickly picking up new techniques, such as performing wet lay-ups of carbon fibre, basic circuitry and drafting iterative payload designs. Currently investigating UV-induced DNA damage via an in-flight sterilization system, intended for future use as a safe sample retrieval system to facilitate sample retrieval from potentially water-bearing planets. We are investigating the conserved DNA repair pathways in prokaryotes and eukaryotes, namely, the role of bacterial recA and eukayotic recA homologs in DNA repair. The effects of launch conditions on this particular protein will be investigated using Saccharomyces cerevisiae recA homolog knockouts (rad52, rad52) transformed with recA in the lab. https://onlineacademiccommunity.uvic.ca/rocketry/team/

name: Will Barr
about: Will is currently a first-year Ph.D. student in Biology at MIT. He is interested in synthetic biology applied to problems of sustainability and disease. Previously, Will was a research assistant in Paul Cohen's Laboratory of Molecular Metabolism at The Rockefeller University using chemical biology to study the endocrine role of brown and beige fat. This work eventually led to awarding of NIH grant 1RC2DK129961-01. Prior to this, Will conducted undergraduate and master's level research in projects supported by NIH grant 1R15GM120719-01 in the Weir Lab at Wesleyan University. Will also has a diverse set of experiences in leadership and writing roles. Will fundamentally believes that there are no unsolveable problems—scientific or social.

Felix-Ortiz, AC & Tye, KM. (2013) Amygdala inputs to the ventral hippocampus bidirectionally modulate social behavior. Journal of Neuroscience 

Felix-Ortiz, AC.*, Beyeler, A.*, Seo, C., Leppla, C., Wildes, C., Tye, KM. (2013) BLA to vHPC inputs modulate anxiety-related behaviors.  Neuron, 79(4): 658-664.

Anxiety disorders, which include posttraumatic stress disorder, social phobias and obsessive-compulsive disorder, affect 40 million American adults in a given year. Currently available treatments, such as antianxiety drugs, are not always effective and have unwanted side effects.

As part of the COR-NIMH program, I worked on the role of gene transcription in the extinction of fear memories, which introduced me to behavioral experiments, injections and data analysis in Sandra Pena de Ortiz’s laboratory.  During the following three years, I continued my work in Sandra’s laboratory studying the role of cAMP Responsive Element Binding protein (CREB) on extinction memory, which is known to be one of the factors that is affected in people who have post-traumatic stress disorder.  I learned molecular techniques such as DNA amplification and genotyping and designed my own protocol to access extinction memory using CREB transgenic mice.  I also had the opportunity to present my work at several international conferences that exposed me to high quality research outside Puerto Rico.

CS Sidekicks

I am a researcher on the Duke University Bass Connections Team: Improving Girls’ Math Identity through Problem-Solving and Mentorship. This project aims to address two major causes of the gender gap in STEM by planning and running a series of free workshops for middle school girls, designed to improve their math identity. Using R, I perform data analyses to help assess the impact of the workshops on girls’ spatial reasoning skills, confidence, and engagement in math and other STEM subjects.
Improving Girls’ Math Identity through Problem-solving and Mentorship (2020-2021)

Duke University Greenhouse - Donohue Research Lab Undergraduate Team
Aug 2019 - Dec 2019 · 5 mos
I conducted field experiments to learn more about the traits that may ensure survival of individual plants and the population-level effects of those traits, like dispersal. I aimed to assess mounting threats to plant populations such as habitat fragmentation and changing climatic conditions pose. This study is part of a larger global experiment called GrENE-net which aims to identify genetic loci associated with local adaptation across a native and introduced a geographic range of Arabidopsis thaliana.
The Donohue Lab
Engineering 101 - Smart Blinds
I created self-sufficient, autonomous, and retrofitted shades that appropriately adjust based on lux measured from ambient light sensor incident on the window. I developed an algorithm to optimize heat entrance and exit to save money and decrease energy use. The system executed by an internal rod, servo, and Arduino Nano use. The final prototype was installed in the client’s home. This project was part of the semester-long design course Engineering 101: Engineering Design and Communications at Duke University.

name: Zin Lin
about: My research focuses on modeling, inverse design, and characterization of nanophotonic geometries, with an aim towards novel functionalities and ultra-compact form factors. It draws on multiple areas of expertise including physics of light-matter interactions, computational electromagnetics, image processing and computer vision as well as nano-structure fabrication and characterization. In particular, my recent efforts have been focused on multi-scale multi-modal physical engineering design where fundamental physical processes in nano-structures are tightly engineered into larger systemic frameworks via large-scale optimization.  You are invited to check out my publication record as well as citations and scholarly indices on my Google Scholar profile: https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=3ZgzHLYAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao I always welcome opportunities to collaborate as well as speak about my past and current research. You can reach me at zinlin@alumni.harvard.edu.

My interests include but not limited to engineering nonlinear optical effects in nano-devices, enhancing light-matter interactions beyond the Purcell effect, quantum optics and information processing, as well as applications of advanced Mathematical techniques to the modeling and development of novel photonic systems.

MIT Integrated Design & Management (IDM) is an innovation leadership program dedicated to developing thoughtful, inspired leaders by way of human-centered design and interdisciplinary collaboration. During the two-year masters degree program at MIT, IDM prepares future leaders who look at problems through the eyes of their stakeholders, connect design with the needs of people who will ultimately judge and use the product, and drive innovation with empathy, passion and process. about: Varsity student-athlete currently pursuing a double major in Environmental Science & Policy and Statistics & Data Science degree. Looking to pursue Ph.D. in computational marine biology after Smith. Motivated leader with a history of a strong work ethic and attention to detail. experience:
Smith College
3 mos
Research Assistant Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship (SURF) Program
May 2022 - Present · 1 mo
Examining the impacts of increasing temperatures on the thermal tolerance and distribution of oysters and blue mussels in the New England rocky intertidal ecosystem. Measuring oyster and blue mussel thermal tolerance will help predict the future distribution of these species as oceans continue to warm. The research consists of field surveys and collecting bivalves for lab experiments. Lab experiments will assess suspension-feeding and growth rates, along with overall survivorship, at varying temperatures (ambient and slightly elevated to simulate a rise in seawater temperatures). Assessing these effects in these already well-documented organisms will provide nuance to potential mitigation and conservation strategies of the rocky intertidal ecosystems of New England.

name: Hari Balakrishnan
about: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hari_Balakrishnan
experience:
Founder; Chairman & CTO
Cambridge Mobile Telematics
2010 - Present · 12 yrs 5 mos
Cambridge MA
Cambridge Mobile Telematics (CMT) seeks to make the world's roads and drivers safer. It uses innovative mobile sensing, statistics, AI, and behavioral science to accurately measure driving quality, improve driving behavior, and help people in car crashes with real-time assistance. CMT's DriveWell program pioneered "behavior-based insurance" using smartphone telematics in 2012, and has added many enhancements since. In 2014, CMT invented the DriveWell Tag IoT device, the first low-power BLE-based sensor device to augment smartphone sensors for accurate measurements of both vehicular dynamics. As of 2020, CMT has shipped over 16 million Tags. CMT's Claims Studio provides crash detection for real-time assistance and AI-based crash reconstruction for better claims processing. CMT's products and solutions are now being used by several million users worldwide (25 countries as of mid-2020) in popular mobile applications, triggering significant changes in the global insurance market. CMT has received numerous awards and honors from TU-Automotive, Celent, TiE, and other organizations, and is today the world's largest and leading telematics service provider. 

Founded based on pioneering research from MIT CSAIL, and located across the street from MIT in Cambridge, CMT has attracted a strong team of engineers, researchers, product, and business leaders in mobile sensing and IoT, AI, cloud infrastructure, data science, statistics, and insurtech. See http://www.cmtelematics.com for more information.

We are hiring for many roles, and are also always interested in anyone with the qualifications and desire to work on these problems! Please see https://www.cmtelematics.com/who-we-are/join-our-team/ to learn more.

Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Aug 1998 - Present · 23 yrs 10 mos

I co-founded and served as the Faculty Co-Director of Wireless@MIT, a Center for Wireless and Mobile Computing launched at MIT as a partnership between academia and industry. Teaching includes various courses on networks, IoT and mobile computing, and computer systems. Joined as Assistant Professor in 1998, received tenure as Associate Professor in 2003, promoted to Professor in 2006.

Meraki

Advisor to Meraki from its pre-founding days. Meraki was a pioneer in delivering low-cost, reliable wireless mesh networks to the world. One of the technologies it developed was cloud-based network management for Wi-Fi networks, which helped it succeed with compelling products in the enterprise access point business as well.
Co-founder
StreamBase Systems
Jun 2003 - Jun 2008 · 5 yrs 1 mo
Co-founded this spin-off that was based on academic research on data stream processing technologies.  StreamBase was the first commercial stream processing engine, a category now called "complex event processing".  The software enables users to rapidly build systems that analyze and act on real-time streaming data for rapid decision-making. StreamBase was subsequently acquired by TIBCO.

name: Ola Ozernov-Palchik
about: Ola Ozernov-Palchik is a program director and lecturer for the MBE program at HGSE. She is also a postdoctoral associate at the McGovern Institute for Brain Research at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in John Gabrieli’s research group. Ozernov-Palchik applies neuroimaging, psychoeducational, and cognitive methods to investigating individual differences in dyslexia in emerging readers. She is interested in the interplay between children and their environment in shaping the development of reading skills. In addition to her current position at MIT, she has worked and collaborated with research teams at Boston Children’s Hospital, Tufts University, MGH Institute of Health Professionals, Boston University, The Technion (Israel Institute of Technology), University of Oregon, and Southern Methodist University (SMU). Before transitioning to cognitive neuroscience research of reading and language development, Ozernov-Palchik worked for six years in the Institute for Evidence Based Education at SMU conducting educational research evaluating reading and math curricula and developing an early literacy assessment.She received a B.S. in psychology and an M.S. in counseling from Southern Methodist University. She received her Ph.D. in cognitive science and child development from Tufts University. She is a recent recipient of International Dyslexia Association Early Career Researcher Award for Contributions to Research. The reciprocity between research and real-world practices is an important goal of her work, and in addition to scientific publications and presentations, she has been speaking and writing to parents, teachers, and legislatures on the topics of early dyslexia identification and remediation.

name: Deborah Liverman, PhD
about: Career Services Leader with over 20 years of experience working with students and professionals. I started my career as a teacher and view career counseling as a way to connect with students and help them discover how they can use their education and experience to find their career paths.  I consider myself a thoughtful career professional that challenges my clients to identify and accomplish career goals.At MIT,  I set the strategic direction for Career Advising and Professional Development by working with groups, departments, employers, graduate and professional programs, fellowship programs, to provide opportunities centered on career development and success for MIT students, postdoc scholars, and recent alumni. She leads and oversees Career Services, Distinguished Fellowships, Prehealth Advising, and Professional Development. Because of my direct work with students, I enjoy conversing with employers about how to attract talent to their companies, particularly STEM students,  women, and underrepresented minority students. I am a researcher at heart and enjoy bringing people and data together to affect change, make progress, and reevaluate what we do for students.   I have completed qualitative and quantitative studies on the career outcomes of undergraduate and graduate students. I have presented at regional and national conferences on career outcomes for college students and advised colleagues on best practices for career outcomes surveys.   I manage the office's data on the first destinations of MIT graduates as well as other surveys.  My professional expertise lies in individual career coaching, assessment, recruiting students in STEM fields, graduate student advising, and working with students from diverse backgrounds.I am creative in my approach to programs, projects, and problem-solving and exercise this skill set both in my professional work and my involvement in external committees.You can connect with me via InMail.

name: Sophie Gibert
about: I am a fourth-year PhD candidate in MIT's Philosophy Department. I received my BA from Wellesley College in 2016, where I studied philosophy, biology, and public health. Before coming to MIT, I spent two years as a pre-doctoral fellow in the Clinical Center Department of Bioethics at the National Institutes of Health, where my research focused on the ethics of measures that aim to improve health behaviorMy current research interests are in ethics, metaethics, and the philosophy of action. I am especially interested in the ethics of manipulation and other forms of influence, especially as implemented by large public and private entities. I am also interested in the ethics of technology and ethics pedagogy. I serve as the Assistant Director for Experiential Ethics, MIT's new ethics of technology course for undergraduates, and as a Teaching Fellow for Embedded EthiCS at Harvard.Originally from Boulder, Colorado, I enjoy hiking, spending time outside, and exploring new parts of the East coast.

In this role, I supported the Restaurant Initiative by recruiting, interviewing, hiring, and training a team of 50 Research Assistants to collect data for a study that assesses children’s orders and consumption patterns in quick-service restaurants. In addition, I wrote and revised training materials, conducted in-person and video trainings, and coordinated the study schedule, materials, and transportation. Other projects included compiling and organizing statistics on the health status of communities using U.S. Census data, Community Commons, and other data sources, and preparing materials for convenings.
Intern, Restaurant Initiative
Aug 2015 - May 2016 · 10 mos
ChildObesity180, housed within Tufts University's Friedman School of Nutrition Science and Policy, is a national leader in childhood obesity prevention that brings together scientific evidence and expertise from the private sector to design, implement, and evaluate high-impact initiatives to target the issue of childhood obesity. These initiatives aim to reach 80% of children ages 5-12 in the United States and are strategic to reach those children disproportionately affected by obesity. The Restaurant Initiative, the broad goal of which is to reduce excess calorie consumption that occurs in the restaurant setting, works both to increase consumer demand for healthy kids' meals and to conduct and disseminate original research in partnership with leading restaurants to inform the industry as a whole of the benefits of providing healthier menu options.

As an Intern with the Restaurant Initiative, I researched relevant policies and produced policy briefings, read and summarized relevant scientific literature, prepared materials for grant applications, and designed shirts, stickers, and other promotional materials to support a messaging campaign. I also supervised a team of data collectors in the restaurant setting and assisted in data entry.

The NORC Summer Research Program is a 10-week paid internship that matches undergraduate or medical students with participating research mentors at institutions in the area in order to inspire passion toward research in obesity and nutrition. In addition to conducting research with their mentors, students attend weekly Core lectures presented by Mid-Atlantic NORC faculty that cover topics in nutrition and obesity-related chronic diseases and weekly Journal Club meetings, where relevant articles are read and discussed.

Under the mentorship of Dr. Sara N. Bleich, Associate Professor at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health in the Department of Health Policy and Management, I assisted with research related to national menu labeling regulations. Projects included categorizing the subject matter of over 11,000 fast-food restaurant advertisements developed by the top 66 U.S. chains, researching the content and impact of fast-food restaurant advertising to children in the U.S. using PubMed and JSTOR databases, and summarizing these findings in a report. In accordance with the Mid-Atlantic NORC curriculum, I also wrote a short manuscript and presented a summary of my research to peers and participating research mentors at the University of Maryland.

The ECF is an annual recruiting event that connects employers from Europe with the most talented candidates in the US.

This career fair is the largest of its kind in the United States and has a proven track record providing domestic, foreign, and multinational companies access to some of the highest caliber applicants worldwide. Our candidates are students, working professionals and recent alums of Ivy League, and renowned European and American universities. name: Akash Srivastava
about: In my day job at the MIT-IBM AI Research Lab in Cambridge, MA, I wear a couple of hats:As the technology lead, I am currently driving the product development and innovation efforts in Synthetic Data Generation for the Financial Services Sector.As a principal investigator and research scientist, I am currently working on 1. Self-supervised learning with Prof Pulkit Agarwal’s group, 2. Hybrid generative models for Tabular Data and Engineering Design with Prof Faez Ahmed’s group, 3. Density ratio estimation with Prof Michael U. Gutmann and more recently, on 3. Machine common-sense and intuitive physics with Prof Josh Tenenbaum's group and 4. Causal discovery with Prof Caroline Uhler. Before joining MIT-IBM, I obtained my PhD at the University of Edinburgh where I worked with Prof Charles Sutton and Prof Michael U. Gutmann on generative models for synthetic data generation.My research is currently supported by:1. PI, Climate Change AI, 2022: Towards greener last-mile operations: Supporting cargo-bike logistics through optimized routing of multi-modal urban delivery fleets.2. PI, MIT-IBM, 2021: Hybrid Generative Models. In collaboration with Prof. Faez Ahmed (MIT)3. Co-PI, MIT-IBM, 2021: Representation Learning as a Tool for Causal Discovery. Led by Prof. Caroline Uhler (MIT) and Kristjan H Greenewald (MIT-IBM Research)4. PI, MIT-IBM, 2020: Learning Priors for Transfer. In collaboration with Prof. Pulkit Agarwal (MIT)5. name: María Eugenia Inda
about: I'm a Pew postdoctoral fellow in the Lu Lab at MIT. I'm working on the development of novel noninvasive strategies for the early diagnosis and alleviation of inflammation in intestinal disorders, such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). A variety of bacteria inhabit healthy human intestines, so we've been working to commandeer some of these microbes for use as “sentinels” that could patrol the gut and secrete therapeutic molecules in areas that appear inflamed. I'm equipping bacteria with biosensors that recognize the molecular markers of IBD—and then trigger the release of anti-inflammatory compounds. I'm assessing the engineered microbes’ ability to distinguish between diseased and healthy tissue and to treat inflammation in an animal models of IBD.
experience:
Massachusetts Institute of Technology
4 yrs 10 mos
MIT Communication Lab advisor
Oct 2017 - Present · 4 yrs 8 mos
Cambridge, MA
Eugenia knows the importance of mastering communication skills for pushing her scientific career forward. She used her prowess to show evaluators the value of her ideas in order to become a Pew Postdoctoral Fellow in the Synthetic Biology Center at MIT. In Timothy Lu’s lab, she’s investigating the bacteria dwelling in our intestines. Specifically, she’s working to commandeer some of these microbes for use as “sentinels” that could be engineered to patrol the gut and recognize the molecular markers of inflammatory disease. She received a doctorate in Microbiology in 2014 from the National University of Rosario, Argentina, where she was a teaching assistant and directed undergraduate theses. She’s thrilled to be a part of the Comm Lab because helping colleagues develop their communication skills is meaningful to her as a contribution to both scientists and Science, as a whole. Outside her research, she loves capturing the beauty of everyday life with her Nikon D3400 camera.

name: Steven Meisler
about: I am a PhD Student in the Harvard-MIT program in Speech and Hearing Bioscience and Technology. I graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a Master's and Bachelor's degree in bioengineering with minors in jazz studies, mathematics, and engineering entrepreneurship. I am also an avid jazz musician (primarily a vibraphonist since 2008), and have sought opportunities to jointly pursue my passions for engineering and music. I am interested in using multimodal neuroimaging and elctrophysiological approaches to explore the relationship between brain structure and function, using neurodevelopmental and learning disorders as models. I would enjoy connecting with anyone who shares a similar intrigue in the intersection of arts, neuroscience, and engineering.

name: Hassaam Ali
about: I am a master's candidate at MIT in business, design and engineering jointly at Sloan School of Management and School of Engineering. My three areas of expertise are Strategy, Operation and Product Management. I thrive in diverse teams to solve challenging problems using my swiss knife of skills. I have 7 years of in-depth experience in product management, pricing strategy and supply chain operations, working in 3 geographies with leading companies focused from technology to FMCGs. I have managed teams of engineers, designers and business strategists to successfully develop and deliver end-to-end products and solutions at scale.I am passionate about technology and human centered design, and how they can transform organizations and markets by creating positive impact for customers through innovation. I have strong data and business analytics skills that I use as guiding factors along with rigorous user experience research to make strategic decisions. I am well versed with leading technical teams and projects, Agile methodology, HCD process, pricing architecture, product and service design, value stream mapping, budget planning and demand forecasting. I follow these methodologies to solve problems, prioritize focus areas and build efficient solutions that reduce time to market and increase customer satisfaction. I believe in constant learning, failing fast and that a team can be be greater than its parts through inclusive collaborative work culture. I have interest in entrepreneurial and innovation ecosystems in emerging nations. My thesis explores frameworks that best enable these ecosystems to create sustainable value and grow at a fast pace.

the 44th World Youth Rally participant
Hostelling International
Jul 2019 · 1 mo
Songpa-gu, Seoul, Korea
“Be friends, Best friends" is the slogan of WYR. "Best friends" is not just friends but friends beyond prejudice and differences by understanding each other.

Together with 13 participants from China, we joined the 44th World Youth Rally in Seoul organized by Hostelling International Korea, with over 60 participants from 12 countries such as China, Korea, Germany, France, Canada, Australia, Malaysia, Qatar, Iran, Sudan and Yemen. During the 5 days together, we had lot of meaningful discussions and activities.
1. We had youth forum where we shared our bucket list, found people sharing similar values and discussed how we can design our life goals considering the United Nations sustainable development goals.
2. We had team tasks taking photos representing UN SDGs and group debates leveraging critical thinking skills to review heated issues related to SDGs.
3. We visited the war memorial of Korea and had a panel discussion with TNKR, an NPO aimed at assiting North Korean refugees in preparing for their future and transitioning to life outside of North Korea.
4. I was the main presenter introducing how China is doing in terms of SDGs. I also shared my stories on how language exchange, couchsurfing and public speaking experience have helped me to see a bigger world and encouraged people to adopt life-long learning mentality.

education:
MIT Sloan School of Management
Doctor of Philosophy - PhD, Managerial Science - System Dynamics, minor Operations Management
2018 - 2023
System Dynamics is a methodological framework to understand, design, and manage change. Using data and technology, System Dynamics models the relationships between all the parts of a system and how those relationships influence the behavior of the system over time. I'm interested in studying complex systems in which upstream decision making (with imperfect information) has long-term consequences, often beyond the attention span of the original decision maker. Examples include an extended view of product life-cycle management that stretches from initial concept to final product disposition. I'm especially interested in the wider costs of product/system failure and recalls.

name: Courtney (Sharpe) Jacobovits
about: A constant in my career has been removing barriers to help people thrive. In all my endeavors I seek understanding and connection. I believe in meeting people where they are to help them get to where they want to be. I am fascinated by the reality that everything is interconnected. To expand my awareness, I have studied history, religion, design, urban planning, finance, and sustainability. Due to a longstanding love of people and culture I have taken courses in Spanish, French, German, Italian, Hebrew, Turkish, Korean, Modern Standard Arabic (Fusha), and Moroccan Arabic (Darija). On my own I have also studied Portuguese, Russian, and Romanian. While I only claim fluency in English my reading comprehension remains strong across the romance languages. My interests are broad and I wouldn't want it any other way. I am a frequent panelist on topics related to design, diversity, urban planning, and cultural matters. I have been a guest lecturer at Harvard College, Harvard Graduate School of Design (GSD), Wentworth Institute of Technology, and Northwestern University. I have been an architecture, landscape architecture, and urban planning critic for institutions such as the GSD, University of Michigan, and Boston Society of Landscape Architects. If asked, I'll happily answer questions about myself and have done so for countless students and job seekers. I've also been interviewed for a couple of podcasts and have been featured in a print edition of Metropolis magazine. I have had pieces published published in design anthologies and Jewish community blogs.If my interests resonate with you, let's talk! Send me a message about what we could do together. Let's find out where our dreams can take us!Strengths Finder Top 5: Futuristic, Intellection, Responsibility, Context, Restorative

I managed the construction costs for the main tunnels of the central section of "London's Super Sewer". This section of the works consisted of 12.7 km of tunnels excavated with two TBMs under the River Thames, serving as an upgrade to London's existing sewage system. As part of my duties, I had to define and maintain a budget for the entire Scope of Work, including labour, plant and materials. 

Besides, I reported monthly the EVM performance of the project defining the main KPIs (such as CPI, SPI, Target vs. Cost) and generating visual dashboards to reflect key insights in a visual manner.  Following this exercise, I acted as a link between the Project Controls team and the Construction team, defining cost-saving strategies and translating the potential risk into quantifiable value for decision-making purposes.

In the forecasting side, I was responsible for producing a monthly short term forecast based on the Program to Build and the Contract/P.O.s terms and a semi-annually long term forecast for cash-flow.

name: Nur Ahmed
about: I am a Postdoc at MIT Sloan & MIT CSAIL. I completed my PhD from Ivey Business School, Canada and was a Research Fellow at the ScotiaBank Digital Banking Lab. My focus is broadly on Innovation, entrepreneurship and technology strategy.For the latest update please see: https://www.nurahmed.com/My research examines firms’ innovation and technology strategy, more specifically corporate science and R&D disclosure strategy. I examine the factors that motivate firms to pursue basic scientific research and voluntarily disclose internal research in the public domain (e.g., publications, patents). To this end, I build a research program of corporate R&D using Artificial Intelligence as an empirical context. Further, I examine the role of specialized assets like computing power and data in innovation processes. Drawing on strategic management literature, and using Big Data, Machine learning (NLP) and interviews, I build testable models of the world that can help managers to make decisions.

name: David V Capodilupo
about: David Capodilupo has over 40 years of executive level experience across client services, process improvement, sales and marketing with leading investment firms.  His accomplishments range from  process improvement/change management, project management and team leadership within financial services and higher education.  David has held Senior Vice President positions in operations, sales and marketing functions.   His responsibilities included Brokerage Services, Family Office, Shareholder and 401(k) Client Services, and Trust Operations.At MIT, David was appointed Executive Director of the MBA and Masters of Management Studies Programs.  David is currently the Assistant Dean for MIT Management's Global Programs.  His program's portfolio includes established collaborations with Masters Programs and academic institutions within Malaysia, China, Korea, Australia, Portugal, India, Russia, Turkey, Taiwan, Chile and Brazil.  David's global responsibilities also include MIT's REAP (Regional Entrepreneurship  Acceleration Program) and the Visiting Fellows Program.  David  initiated and manages the MIT Sloan Latin America Office in Santiago, Chile.He founded Aspen Concepts, LLC, a consulting firm specializing in environmental investments with the Chinese Government, and, TribeHive, LLC, a firm focusing on software development for executive training and placement. David is a member of The Boeing 727 Prototype Restoration Team, Board of Directors, Future of Flight Museum, Everett, WA, and a Board Member of the Global Business School Network, Washington, DC.  David also serves on the Board of Trustees for the Concord Museum, Concord, MA, the MIT Sloan Latin America Advisory Council, and the Advisory Council for Greens Farms Academy, CT.  He is a former board member of the MIT Sloan School North American Executive Board and The MassArt Foundation.

about: At MIT Sloan School of Management, I am part of a team that aims to help MIT Sloan fulfill it's mission to develop principled, innovative leaders who improve the world and to generate ideas that advance management practice. My goal at MIT Sloan is to encourage new ideas and innovative methods of best practices that can be used across every group at Sloan, to foster good communication and to promote distributed leadership. I excel at financial and project management, building relationships and problem solving.

As the Research Services Coordinator, I have the exciting opportunity to help MIT Sloan Faculty fulfill our mission to develop principled, innovative leaders and to generate ideas that advance management practice, by working with Faculty and HR to hire Technical Associates (predoctoral research assistants). The mission and goal of adding this category of research staff to the Sloan portfolio is to not only assist our world-class faculty who are conducting stellar research, but to build a wider, deeper, more inclusive pool of future PhD students with practical research experience who will then go on to become leaders in the industry of their choosing, be it the technology sector, business fields, or academic careers. 

To help satisfy the research needs of our faculty and researchers, I work with the MIT Research Librarians and the Sloan Research Computing team to monitor and streamline our data procurement process, and I work with Sloan Student Funding to coordinate the hiring of course Teaching Assistants and student Research Assistants.

name: Negin (Nicki) Golrezaei
about: Negin Golrezaei is an Assistant Professor of Operations Management at the MIT Sloan School of Management. Her current research interests are in the area of machine learning, statistical learning theory, mechanism design, and optimization algorithms with applications to revenue management, pricing, and online markets. Before joining MIT, Negin spent a year as a postdoctoral fellow at Google Research in New York where she worked with the Market Algorithm team to develop, design, and test new mechanisms and algorithms for online marketplaces.She is the recipient of the 2017 George B. Dantzig Dissertation Award; the INFORMS Revenue Management and Pricing Section Dissertation Prize; University of Southern California (USC) Ph.D. Achievement Award (2017), and USC CAMS Graduate Student Prize, for excellence in research with a substantial mathematical component (2017), and USC Provost’s Ph.D. Fellowship (2011).

name: Johanna Hising DiFabio
about: I have the privilege of directing all administrative aspects of these distinguished senior mid-career MBA degrees, housed within MIT Management’s Sloan School.  Each year, MIT offers 360 global professionals the opportunity to earn their MBA degrees on campus.I lead all administrative aspects of the programs.  Specifically, by collaborating with faculty on the development of innovative curricula; with global organizations on action learning labs to help them meet pressing strategic issues; and, most importantly, with our students to create a learning environment that is second-to-none in terms of the personal development and career enhancement. Working with mid-career executives is my passion and the main reason for my joining MIT in 2010.   I’ve spent my entire career in the area of adult learning, particularly in leadership development, and MIT Sloan is one of the best environments in the world for this. This is due in large part to the Institute’s dedication to action learning, and because of this, we fundamentally change the way students approach challenges and opportunities. It pushes them to rethink how they’ve done things in the past, to apply new lenses and skills to problems, and to create and drive positive change.  Our work together truly reflects MIT Sloan’s mission: “to develop principled, innovative leaders who improve the world and to generate ideas that advance management practice.”The global nature of our community is something that is very important to me personally.  My own cultural lens of how communities come together to learn, both from our similarities and differences, are essential themes that I foster within our dynamic learning environment.  I grew up in Europe, am a Swedish citizen, came to the US to pursue my education.  I also have a young family and we have demanding jobs.  I appreciate how our students make the commitment and sacrifices that it takes to pursue an endeavor as ambitious as our MBA programs.

Behavioral researcher around how we use and depend on technology.Partial Bio: For over 20 years, Ja-Naé Duane focused on one mission: To help 1 million entrepreneurs create impact. This award-winning innovator has done that by focusing on revolutionary ideas and develop programs that impact our world. Currently, Ja-Naé is the co-founder of The Revolution Factory, helping global organizations and startups to achieve revolutionary transformation through an innovation network that enables them to make the right connections to bring strategies to life and build companies that are future resilient. This co-author of the bestseller, “The Startup Equation,” is a sought-after speaker in the future of systems, the economics of the Metaverse, entrepreneurship, distributed networks, and collective intelligence. “If there is one word to describe Ja-Nae, it’s passion. Ja-Nae is driven by the passion she has for the work she does. And there is no one that knows her way around the social sphere better than Ja-Nae. Bring those two elements together and you get a smart, strategic, committed, dedicated, and driven individual who honestly loves what she does.”   – Diego Vaccarezza, Director of Advertising Media at CVS

about: I graduated in 2019 with my bachelors degree in Technical Communication with a minor in Business Administration from the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. After graduation, I moved to Cambridge, MA to work for a cyber security research group at MIT, where I have been for the last two years. I have developed a deep interest in cyber security, which has inspired me to take a bootcamp course to train for a career in cyber. I strive to take control of situations, figure out how to solve difficult problems as they arise, engage those around me, and I am a strong advocate for security and privacy. I am experienced in business social media, content creation, technical communications, customer relations, and website management.
